snippet: Brazil restricted Haitian visas in January after about 4,000 Haitians arrived in its Amazon frontier, setting off a discussion about what kind of immigrants the country should try to attract.
abstract: Brazil, faced with an influx of thousands of Haitians into its Amazonian frontier, has begun cracking down, issuing them only 100 temporary work visas per month; restrictions offer a view into Brazil's growing pains as it wields greater regional influence and emerges an immigration magnet; critics contend that policy favors skilled workers from rich countries over poor foreign laborers, even at a time of historically low unemployment when many Brazilian companies are struggling to hire workers.

byline.original: By SIMON ROMERO and ANDREA ZARATE
byline.contributor: Simon Romero reported from Rio de Janeiro, and Andrea Zarate from Lima, Peru. Lis Horta Moriconi and Erika O’Conor contributed reporting from Rio de Janeiro, and William Neuman from Caracas, Venezuela.

lead_paragraph: Brazil restricted Haitian visas in January after about 4,000 Haitians arrived in its Amazon frontier, setting off a discussion about what kind of immigrants the country should try to attract.

headline.main: Influx of Haitians Into the Amazon Prompts Immigration Debate in Brazil
